content:
Yes, it is highly likely that other countries will follow China's example and launch their own infrastructure initiatives in the years to come. The success of the Belt and Road Initiative has shown that significant investments in infrastructure can generate economic growth and development, create jobs, and increase regional and global connectivity. Many countries around the world have infrastructure needs, and there is a growing recognition that investment in this area is vital for their long-term economic success.

Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for more significant investments in infrastructure to create jobs, promote economic recovery, and address longstanding problems such as climate change, digital connectivity, and social inequality. Therefore, countries may be more inclined to launch infrastructure initiatives as part of their post-pandemic recovery strategies.

Furthermore, the launch of the US-led Build Back Better World (B3W) initiative also indicates that other countries may seek to develop their versions of infrastructure initiatives to promote sustainable and inclusive infrastructure development. The B3W initiative seeks to provide a higher-quality alternative to the Belt and Road Initiative and has already gained support from several countries.

Overall, the Belt and Road Initiative has demonstrated that significant investments in infrastructure can drive economic development, and it is likely that we will see more countries launch their infrastructure initiatives to boost their economic prospects in the future. This trend could impact the global order and alter the balance of power in favor of countries with significant infrastructure projects.
